question: イギリス人
sourceMnemonic: イギリス means "Great Britain" or "United Kingdom." So what is a "Great Britain person?" You guessed it — a <vocabulary>British person</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>Brit</vocabulary>.
sourceReadingMnemonic:
Often times, when two kanji come together to form a kanji compound (or jukugo), you use the on'yomi readings. This is similar to that, though instead of another kanji it's a foreign word. This pattern works with almost any country as well. Just add <ja>人</ja> to a country name and you've described the people who live there. You'll see more of these before you're finished here.

And since <ja>人</ja> has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: 

As with all words for nationalities, the <ja>人</ja> here is pronounced <ja>じん</ja>. All nationalities, including <vocabulary>Brit</vocabulary>s, love <reading>jean</reading>s (<ja>じん</ja>)!
